column2: 但我们应该清楚这些变化并不是在边缘修修补补。

column1: They amount to a reversal of decades of policy by American and British regulators.
column2: 它们相当于是美国和英国监管机构几十年政策的逆转。

column1: Ernest Patrikis, a former Fed supervisor, points to the clear implication that in the US domestic banks will have a strong advantage over foreign banks.
column2: 美联储前主管欧内斯特·帕特里基斯（Ernest Patrikis）指出美国国内银行将会比外资银行拥有很强大的优势。

column1: More dramatically, he asserts that “subsidiarization would be the end of international banking.”
column2: 更引人注目地是，他断言“子公司化将是国际银行业的归宿 。 ”

column1: Larry Fink, the CEO of the multinational investment-management firm BlackRock, takes a similar view: “It really throws into question [the] whole globalization of these firms,” with “each country for [itself].”
column2: 跨国投资管理公司黑石集团的总裁拉里·芬克（Larry Fink）也持有类似的观点 ： “ 这些公司的整个全球化都遭到了质疑，每个国家都是为了自己的利益 ” 。

column1: He adds: “I wouldn’t call it a trade war, but I would certainly call it a high level of protectionism.”
column2: 他补充到 ： “ 我不会把这称之为贸易战，但肯定会将其称之为高层次的保护主义 。 ”

column1: One delicious irony in Europe is that Chinese banks are contesting the requirement to subsidiarize in London on precisely those grounds.
column2: 而在欧洲最有趣的讽刺就是中国各大银行恰恰是基于这些理由质疑在伦敦设立子公司的要求。

column1: For now, high-octane worries about protectionism are probably overdone.
column2: 目前对保护主义政策的强烈担忧或许有些过虑了。

column1: And it is difficult to deny that the Fed should take a close interest in the funding strategies of foreign banks operating in the US.
column2: 但也难以否认美联储应该更加关注在美外资银行的融资策略。

column1: Another Fed governor, Jeremy Stein, has pointed out that foreign banks have dollar liabilities of roughly $8 trillion, much of it short-term wholesale funding.
column2: 另一位美联储理事 — — 杰里米·斯坦因（Jeremy Stein）曾指出外资银行有大约8万亿的美元债务，其中大部分是短期的大规模融资。

column1: But there is a risk that these interventions are the thin end of a dangerous wedge.
column2: 但是存在着这样一个风险 — — 即这些干预是一个危险的端倪。

column1: Forced subsidiarization causes capital and liquidity to be trapped in local legal entities, reducing the effectiveness with which that capital is used.
column2: 强制外资银行设立子公司会导致资本和流动性被困在当地的法律实体里，这降低了资本的有效性。

column1: At a time when bank capital is scarce, that impediment carries significant economic costs.
column2: 在银行资本匮乏之时，这种阻碍就将承担着极大的经济成本。

column1: Moreover, tools that may be used wisely and well by institutions with a global outlook, like the Fed and the Bank of England, could take on a different character in countries where a commitment to free and open markets cannot be taken for granted.
column2: 此外，能被具有全球视野的机构 — — 比如美联储和英格兰银行 — — 明智并合理使用的工具在某些国家里可能会呈现不同的特点，因为无法保证这些国家一定会致力于建立自由开放的市场。

column1: So we must hope that the US and British authorities move carefully and do not use their new powers to freeze out foreign competition.
column2: 所以我们不得不希望美英当局小心行事且不要运用它们的新权力来排斥国外竞争。

column1: “Be careful what you wish for” is wise advice in the regulatory world, as it is elsewhere.
column2: “注意你自己的愿望”的忠告不仅适用于别处，对监管者来说也是如此。

column1: Will Next Time Be Different?
column2: 下次会不一样吗？

column1: CHICAGO – Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff, in their excellent, eponymous book on debt crises, argue that the most dangerous words in any language are “This time is different.”
column2: 发自芝加哥 — — 卡门·莱因哈特与肯尼思·罗格夫这两位经济学家曾合著了一本关于债务危机的大作，书中认为最危险的说辞莫过于“这次跟以前不同了 。 ”

column1: Perhaps the next most dangerous words are “Next time will be different.”
column2: 而或许危险程度排名第二的句子则是“下次肯定不会像以往那样 。 ”

column1: These words are often uttered when politicians and central banks want to bail out some troubled segment of the economy.
column2: 每当那些政客和中央银行试图拯救某些陷入麻烦的经济部门时，类似的说辞就会从他们嘴里蹦出来。

column1: “Yes,” one can almost hear them saying, “we understand that bailing out banks will subvert market discipline. But you cannot expect us to stand by and watch the system collapse, causing millions of innocent people to suffer.
column2: 人们几乎可以猜到讲话内容 ： “ 我们明白拯救银行会破坏市场纪律，但你也不能让我们眼睁睁看着整个系统崩溃，让数百万无辜民众受苦受难吧，事已至此，也只能硬着头皮去面对了。

column1: We have to live with the hand we are dealt. But next time will be different.”
column2: 不过我保证下次肯定不会像以往那样的 。 ”

column1: They then use every tool they have to prevent economic losses on their watch.
column2: 然后他们就用尽手中一切手段去制止自己当政期间的一切经济损失。

column1: The government’s incentives are clear.
column2: 政府的动机其实相当明确。

column1: The public rewards them for dealing with the problem at hand – whether building levees to protect houses built on a flood plain or rescuing banks that have dodgy securities on their balance sheets.
column2: 公众总会对他们应对当前问题的作为大加赞赏 — — 无论是兴建堤坝保护洪泛区民居还是拯救那些拥有有毒资产的银行。

column1: Politicians and central bankers gain little by letting the greedy or careless face the full consequences of their actions, for many innocent people would suffer as well.
column2: 而倘若政客和中央银行官员们坐视那些始作俑者自食其果的话（这也会导致许多无辜民众受害 ） ， 他们自己却捞不到什么好处。

column1: A sympathetic press would amplify their heart-rending stories of lost jobs and homes, making those counseling against intervention appear callous.
column2: 一个同情心泛滥的媒体将大肆渲染那些失业和无家可归者的辛酸故事，使得那些反对干涉的意见显得残忍且麻木不仁。

column1: Democracies are necessarily soft-hearted, whereas markets and nature are not; government inevitably expands to fill the gap.
column2: 民主制度总是心太软，而市场和大自然则太过残酷；于是政府便无可避免地挺身而出，填补了双方之间的空白。

column1: To the extent that the rough justice meted out by markets or nature teaches anyone to behave better, it has consequences far beyond the horizon of anyone in power today.
column2: 在某种程度上，正是市场和大自然那些粗暴而公正的惩罚教会了人们谨慎行事，同时这些惩罚也会带来超出当权者预料之外的成果。

column1: When asked to choose between the risk of being known to posterity as the central banker who let the system collapse and the intangible future benefits of teaching risk takers a lesson, it does not take genius to predict the central banker’s decision.
column2: 但倘若要二者选其一：一是作为一个任由系统崩溃的中央银行官员遗臭万年，二是在给那些风险玩家一个教训之后收获不知何时降临的善果，估计很多中央银行家的答案都无法预测。

column1: Democracy tends to institutionalize moral hazard in sectors that are economically or politically important, such as finance or real estate, allowing them to privatize gains and socialize losses.
column2: 民主制度倾向于用政策把那些在政治经济上具有重要意义的部门（比如金融或地产）所面临的道德风险包揽起来，让他们一面私有化其收益，另一面却将风险社会化。

column1: Even though the authorities insist that the next time will be different, everyone knows that they will make the same decision when confronted with the same choice again.
column2: 即便当局坚称下不为例，所有人都知道他们下次肯定还会做出同样的决定。

column1: So, knowing that next time will not be different, the authorities try their best to prevent a “next time.”
column2: 因此在明知下一次不会跟以往不同的情况下，政府会想尽办法避免“下一次 ” 。

column1: But risk takers have every incentive to try their luck again, knowing that, at worst, they will be bailed out.
column2: 但那些金融冒险家们肯定有无数借口继续冒险，因为他们知道就算局面最终无法收拾，还是有人会出手拯救他们。

column1: In this cat-and-mouse game, risk takers have the upper hand.
column2: 可见在这场猫鼠游戏中，冒险家们无疑占了上风。

column1: For one thing, risk takers are typically small, cohesive interest groups that, once rescued, have a powerful incentive, as well as the resources, to buy the political influence needed to ensure a return to the status quo ante.
column2: 首先，这些冒险家属于一个极具凝聚力的小团体，一旦起死回生，他们就有极强的动机（以及资源）去换取所需的政治影响力，好让自己能回复到从前的状况。

column1: If risk takers were allowed to face more serious losses, they would have fewer resources to fight political attempts to constrain their risky activities.
column2: 如果能让这些人面对更严重损失的话，他们就无法拥有那么多资源去抵抗那些限制其冒险行为的政治行动。

column1: Moreover, the public does not have a long memory, a long time horizon, or an appetite for detail.
column2: 此外，公众往往是健忘，短视而且不关注细节的。

column1: Even as the United States’ voluminous Dodd-Frank bill tried to ensure that bankers never subjected American taxpayers to undue risk again, public attention had moved on to the state of the real economy and unemployment.
column2: 当长篇大论的多德-法兰克法案还在试图确保银行家们不再把美国纳税人置于危险中时，公众的注意力早就转移到了实体经济和就业之上。

column1: Why focus on financial regulation when the risks of an immediate collapse are small, and when the details are so tedious?
column2: 在公众眼中既然迅速崩溃的风险已经很小，法律规章的细节又是如此冗长乏味，又何必再着眼于金融管制呢？

column1: As technical experts and lobbyists took over, and the public lost interest, Dodd-Frank became friendlier and friendlier to the banks.
column2: 于是技术官员和国会游说者占据了上风，公众又逐渐失去了兴趣，多德-法兰克法案最终也逐渐向银行利益倾斜。

column1: So how can this one-way betting be stopped?
column2: 那么这种一面倒的情况何时才是尽头？

column1: The scary answer may be that it does not end until governments run out of money (as in Ireland) or the public runs out of sympathy (as in Germany vis-à-vis the rest of Europe).
column2: 最令人心惊的答案莫过于直到政府都没钱了（爱尔兰那样）或者公众没有了同情心（正如德国人对欧洲其他地区的态度）的那一天。

column1: To avoid that fate, governments should start by recognizing that the system is programmed to respond to deep distress, and that they can do nothing about it.
column2: 为了避免这一命运，各国政府应当逐步认识到整个系统早已有了应对深刻危机的一套方法，而且任何人力都无法改变。

column1: But they must try to ensure that they do not destroy incentives by doing too much. And they must offset the distortions created by intervention in other ways.
column2: 但他们必须努力确保不会因为过度作为而损害了市场的内在动力，同时也必须补偿由其他干涉行为而导致的市场扭曲。

column1: For example, the US Federal Reserve has essentially guaranteed the financial sector that if it gets into trouble, ultra-low interest rates will be maintained (at the expense of savers) until the sector recovers.
column2: 比如说，美国联邦储备委员会（简称美联储）就向金融部门保证，一旦后者陷入麻烦就将维持极低利率直到该部门复苏为止。

column1: In the early to mid-1990’s, rates were kept low because of banks’ real-estate problems.
column2: 在1990年代中早期为了解决银行的地产问题而一直压低利率。

column1: They were slashed again in 2001 and kept ultra-low after the dot-com bust.
column2: 随后2001年互联网泡沫爆破，于是利率又再次下滑并维持在极低水平。

column1: And they have been ultra-low since 2008.
column2: 如今的低利率已经从2008年维持至今。

column1: Senior Fed policymakers deny that their interest-rate policy bears any responsibility for risk taking, but there is much evidence to the contrary.
column2: 美联储高级政策制定者否认自身利率政策对冒险行为负有任何责任，但许多证据却告诉了我们一个相反的事实。

column1: It would be difficult for the Fed to respond differently if the financial sector gets into trouble again.
column2: 倘若金融部门再度惹祸上身的话，估计美联储的做法还会是老一套。

column1: But it does not have to maintain ultra-low interest rates after the crisis has passed, especially if those rates have little impact on generating sustainable economic activity.
column2: 但它没必要在危机过后继续维持极低利率，尤其是当这些利率对促进可持续经济活动的作用已经很小的时候。

column1: Doing so merely rewards banks for their past excesses – and taxes savers.
column2: 这种做法���仅是便宜了那些曾经过度放肆的银行 — — 还有那些避税的富人。

column1: More importantly, if the Fed wants to restore incentives for risk takers and savers, it should offset the effects of staying “low for long” in bad times by increasing interest rates more rapidly than is strictly necessary as the economy recovers.
column2: 更重要的是，如果美联储想要恢复冒险者以及储蓄者的动力，就必须停止那在危机时期维持“长期低利率”的做法，转而在复苏时更迅速地升高利率。

column1: This will, of course, be politically difficult, because the public has been programmed to think that ultra-low rates are good, and higher rates bad, for growth, without any consideration for the long-term sustainability of growth.
column2: 这在政治上当然会相当艰难，因为公众早就有了思维定势，认为极低利率肯定好，高利率肯定不好，却根本没有考虑到长期增长的可持续性。

column1: Finally, the pressure on governments to intervene would be lower if individuals had access to a minimum safety net.
column2: 最后，如果民众个人能加入基本的社会安全网络的话，那些要求政府干涉的压力也会得到缓解。

column1: Official US policy is so activist in downturns (regardless of its effectiveness) partly because unemployment is so costly to workers – who have little savings, unemployment benefits that run out quickly, and health care that is often tied to a job.
column2: 美国官方政策之所以在经济不景时如此活跃，某种程度上就是因为劳动阶层对失业极为敏感 — — 他们没有储蓄，失业救济也很快花光，而医疗往往又和工作挂钩。

column1: A stronger safety net for individuals might allow politicians to accept more corporate or financial-sector distress, and help bolster their claim that next time really will be different.
column2: 一个更强大的个人社会安全网将使得政治家能容许企业和金融部门承担更大的压力，并帮助他们实现“下回真的跟以往不一样”的诺言。

column1: Will Olmert Survive?
column2: 奥尔默特能否涉险过关？

column1: After Israel’s inability last summer to achieve a conclusive victory over Hezbollah in southern Lebanon, public pressure forced Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s government to appoint a commission to examine the causes of this surprising failure.
column2: 以色列军队去年夏天未能在南黎巴嫩对真主党取得决定性胜利之后，公众压力迫使总理奥尔默特政府任命一个委员会调查这一出人意料的失败的原因。

column1: How could a small militia, numbering less than a few thousand combatants, survive the onslaught of the Middle East’s most formidable military machine?
column2: 一个人数不过几千人的小小民兵武装何以能够在中东地区最为强悍的军事机器的扫荡中存活下来？

column1: The commission, headed by retired Supreme Court judge Eliyahu Winograd, has just published its interim report.
column2: 由退休的最高法院法官维诺格拉特领导的这一委员会刚刚发表了其临时报告。

column1: Its criticism of Olmert, Defense Minister Amir Peretz, and Chief-of-Staff Dan Halutz – set forth in a detailed and meticulous 117-page assessment – is harsh, but not surprising.
column2: 这一报告严厉批评奥尔默特、国防部长佩雷茨以及总参谋长哈卢茨，并不出人所料，同时还提出了具体而又精确的长达117页的评估。

column1: The Winograd Commission articulated what most Israelis already think: Olmert and Peretz lacked the military, security, and policy experience to confront a terrorist organization that raided Israeli territory, killed a number of soldiers and kidnapped two, and then launched thousands of rockets on civilian targets for over a month.
column2: 维诺格拉特委员会表达了大多数以色列人已经存在的看法，那就是奥尔默特和佩雷茨缺乏军事、安全以及政策经验来面对真主党恐怖组织。 这一恐怖组织袭击以色列领土，杀害数名以色列士兵并且绑架两名士兵，然后又在一个多月的时间里向平民目标发射数以千计的火箭。

column1: Indeed, the inexperience of the prime minister and the defense minister are unprecedented in Israel’s history.
column2: 确实，总理和国防部长经验不足在以色列历史上是前所未有的。

column1: Olmert, who stepped into Ariel Sharon’s shoes as leader of the new Kadima Party, was considered a competent but lackluster parliamentarian – and later mayor of Jerusalem – who was known more for his polemical style than for his political stature or gravitas.
column2: 奥尔默特顶替沙龙成为新组建的前进党领导人，他被认为是一个称职而又没有魅力的议会议员。 他后还作过耶路撒冷市长，其好辩的风格为人所知，要超过其政治地位或实力。

column1: For most Israelis, even those who voted for him as the bearer of Sharon’s legacy after the Gaza disengagement, Olmert thus remained the accidental prime minister.
column2: 对于大多数以色列人而言，即使他们在加沙地带撤军后投票选举奥尔默特作为沙龙的遗产的继承人，他也只还是一个意外的总理。

column1: Likewise, Peretz, a rabble-rousing but effective trade unionist, surprised all when he won the Labor Party’s leadership primary and then chose the defense portfolio over the treasury.
column2: 同样，佩雷茨是一个有效的工会人士，颇能煽动人心。 当他赢得工党领导人初选后没有选择成为财政部长而选择国防部长的时候，大家都感到惊讶。

column1: To many, the duo of Olmert and Peretz seemed to invite trouble.
column2: 对于很多人而言，奥尔默特和佩雷茨这一对组合看起来就会引来麻烦。

column1: Precisely because Israelis are aware of the constant security threat facing their country, they have always believed that their leaders should be able to lead Israel in war – but also to ask the military tough questions when diplomacy may fail.
column2: 正是由于以色列人清楚他们的国家时刻面临安全威胁，他们总是相信，他们的领导人能够在战争中带领以色列，同时，在外交努力失败的时候，他们也能够提出严厉的军事问题。

column1: When such a moment arrived, totally out of the blue (or so it seemed) with Hezbollah’s raid on July 12, 2006, Israel’s two top politicians were completely out of their depth, stumbling into a war for which neither they nor the Israeli Army were prepared.
column2: 当这一时刻来临之际，也就是2006年7月12日真主党完全出乎意料地（或者看起来如此）发动袭击的时候，以色列两位最高的政治人物完全不知所措，匆忙之中应战，他们本人以及以色列陆军都没有做好准备。 在历史上第一次，以色列军队由一名空军将军哈卢茨领导。

column1: The military was led – for the first time in its history – by an Air Force general, Dan Halutz, who believed that everything could be solved by air power, creating a combustible combination of civilian ignorance and military arrogance.
column2: 他相信空中力量可以解决一切问题，从而造成文职领导人的无知以及军队的傲慢。 二者结合就导致局势极度危机。

column1: In measured but devastating prose, the Winograd Commission gives failing marks to all three leaders.
column2: 维诺格拉特报告以克制而又严厉的笔调对所有三位领导人都评定为不及格。

column1: Olmert decided to go into battle recklessly and unaware of the consequences.
column2: 奥尔默特决定仓促作战，不知后果。

column1: Peretz was unable to gauge the strategic implications of his decisions.
column2: 佩雷茨无法预测其决定的政治后果。

column1: And Halutz failed to present the civilian leadership with the full panoply of military options at the army’s disposal.
column2: 而哈卢茨则没有向文职领导人提出军队所有的所有军事选择。

column1: Halutz already resigned a few months ago.
column2: 哈卢茨已经在几个月前辞职。

column1: But both Olmert and Peretz have declared that, despite the Commission’s conclusions, they would not quit: instead, they have vowed to implement the report’s many far-reaching substantive recommendations about policy, strategy, and decision-making processes.
column2: 但是奥尔默特和佩雷茨二人都宣称，尽管委员会作出了这些结论，他们都不会辞职。 相反，他们发誓要落实该报告提出的许多有关政策、战略以及决策过程的范围广泛的实质性建议。

column1: Will Olmert and Peretz be able to stay on?
column2: 奥尔默特和佩雷茨能否留任？

column1: Their coalition government enjoys a comfortable parliamentary majority; nor does the political arithmetic imply a viable parliamentary alternative.
column2: 他们的联合政府在议会中占据较大的多数席位。 政治算术也并不表明可以有能够存活下来的其他的议会组成选择。

column1: But public opinion – volatile and angry – calls for both to resign: a public-opinion poll conducted after the Commission published its report indicated that only 14% of Israelis believe that Olmert should keep his job, while less than 11% support Peretz.
column2: 但是舆论是不定的而又愤怒，要求二人都辞职。 委员会发表其报告后所作的民意调查表明，14％的以色列人相信奥尔默特应当留任，而支持佩雷茨的人不到11 ％ 。

column1: Later this week, demonstrations calling for the government's resignation are planned, and it will become obviously more difficult for the government to continue to function.
column2: 现在已经有人计划在本周晚些时候举行要求政府辞职的游行示威，而这将明显地让政府更加难以继续运作。

column1: There are already rumors about a palace coup within Kadima, aimed at replacing Olmert with either the deputy prime minister, the veteran Shimon Peres, or the popular foreign minister, Tzipi Livni.
column2: 现在已经有传言说前进党内部要有宫廷政变，目的在于用副总理、元老佩雷斯或者广受欢迎的外长利夫尼取代奥尔默特。

column1: But it does not appear that Olmert will allow himself to be pushed out.
column2: 但是看起来奥尔默特是不会允许然自己被赶走的。

column1: In fact, Olmert’s weak and discredited government may yet survive.
column2: 实际上，奥尔默特软弱而又饱受垢病的政府可能还是可以存活下来。

column1: If the government were to fall and new elections held, there are strong indications that the winner might be Binyamin Netanyahu, of the right-wing Likud, which was decimated in the 2006 elections, but is now patiently waiting in the wings.
column2: 如果政府倒台，举行新的选举，获胜者很有可能是右翼利库德集团的内塔尼亚胡。 该党在2006年的选举中一败涂地，但是现在却耐心等待时机。

column1: Many who want Olmert to go would still not welcome a Netanyahu comeback, which may also explain what appears to be an indirect endorsement of Olmert by the United States.
column2: 许多想要奥尔默特下台的人还是不会欢迎内塔尼亚胡卷土重来，这也就是为何美国间接地支持奥尔默特的原因了。

column1: Only a strong Israeli government can make the painful decisions necessary for negotiations with the Palestinians to succeed.
column2: 只有一个强大的以色列政府才能够作出并实施与巴勒斯坦谈判所必要的痛苦决定。

column1: As a result, the prospects for meaningful continuation of Israeli-Palestinian talks look even dimmer than they did before.
column2: 结果，���以会谈有意义地进行下去的前景要比过去看起来还要暗淡。

column1: Indeed, the real loser of the 2006 Lebanon war was neither Israel nor Hezbollah, but, at least for the time being, the peace process.
column2: 确实，2006年黎巴嫩战争中真正的失败者既不是以色列也不是真主党，而是中东和平进程，至少目前如此。

column1: Will Rising Interest Rates Torpedo Stock and House Prices?
column2: 利率上升会危及股价和房价吗？

column1: Interest rates around the world are poised to rise.
column2: 世界范围内的银行利率都呈上升之势。

column1: Short-term rates have gone so low since the worldwide recession of 2001 - 1% and 2%, respectively, in the United States and the Eurozone, and practically zero in Japan - that a strengthening world economy will force central banks to tighten the monetary reins.
column2: 短期利率自2001年世界经济不景气以来已降到如此之低-美国和欧元区的利率分别为1%和2 % ， 日本的利率几乎为零-以至于正在走强的世界经济会迫使各国央行收紧货币政策。

column1: Australia's central bank has already been raising rates since May 2002, and Great Britain's since November 2003.
column2: 澳大利亚中央银行自2002年5月以来就一直在调高利率，英国自2003年11月以来也一直在这么做。

column1: In the US, the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting on June 29-30 is likely to mark a major turning point, reversing the steady decline of the benchmark federal funds rate since Alan Greenspan began loosening monetary policy in 2001.
column2: 在美国，即将于6月29-30日召开的联邦开放市场委员会会议可能会标志一个重要的转折点。 它会扭转自格林斯潘2001年放松货币政策以来基准联邦基金利率持续降低的趋势。

column1: This is likely to be followed by rate increases in China, the Eurozone, and elsewhere.
column2: 这有可能进一步带动中国、欧元区和其它地区调高利率。

column1: Given the tendency of central banks to change interest rates gradually, any change of direction likely means more changes in the same direction later.
column2: 由于各国央行通常会逐渐调整利率，所以某一大方向上的调整往往意味着一种持续而来的趋势。

column1: What will this landmark change mean for prices of such assets as stocks and homes?
column2: 这一重大调整对诸如股票和住房一类的资产又意味着什么呢？

column1: In theory, when interest rates go up, there is reason to believe that asset prices will go down.
column2: 从理论上讲，当利率提高时，人们就有理由相信资产价格会走低。

column1: The higher interest rates go, the better are investments in bonds, which compete with investments in other assets such as stocks or homes.
column2: 利率越高，债券的投资行情就越被看好。 投资债券与投资股票和房产是一种竞争的关系。

column1: Higher interest rates also raise the cost of borrowing to buy these assets, which may diminish demand for them, exerting downward pressure on their prices.
column2: 更高的利率还会使用于购买这些资产的贷款成本增加。 增加的贷款成本可能会减少人们对这些资产的需求，并给这些资产施加降价的压力。

column1: When interest rates fall, the opposite effect on asset prices may be predicted.
column2: 而当利率调低时，人们就能预测其会对资产价格产生相反的作用。

column1: In fact, the history of the stock market's reactions to changing interest rates is mixed.
column2: 从实际上看，股票市场对利率变化的反应是混合的。

column1: Sometimes interest rate changes have the predicted effect, sometimes they don't.
column2: 有时利率变化会带来人们意料之中的影响，而有时却不尽然。

column1: For example, the NASDAQ stock price index made a spectacular 14% jump upwards on the day (January 3, 2001) when America's Fed began its latest series of interest rate cuts.
column2: 例如，在美联储开始其最近的一系列降息的那一天（2001年1月3日）纳斯达克股价指数暴涨14 % 。

column1: A jump in the market is what one might have expected.
column2: 股价急升也许是人们意料之中的。

column1: But then the NASDAQ index fell 22% over the following year, although the Fed continued to cut interest rates aggressively.
column2: 可虽然美联储继续大幅调低利率，纳斯达克指数在次年却下滑了22 % 。

column1: Does that experience suggest that the NASDAQ index will drop sharply if the Fed raises interest rates on June 30?
column2: 根据以往的经验，纳斯达克指数会在美联储6月30日调高利率之后急剧下滑吗？

column1: No.
column2: 答案是否定的。

column1: The timing of the 2001 rate decrease stunned the market.
column2: 2001年的降息让市场措手不及。

column1: By contrast, the Fed is widely expected to raise rates at the end this month, so there will be no surprise element.
column2: 相比之下，美联储在这个月底调高利率已在人们的意料之中，所以其中不存在突然性的元素。

column1: The market may know, not just from the experience of 2001-2, that interest rate movements do not have predictable effects on stock prices.
column2: 市场可能会明白（不光从2001-2的经验当中）利率的波动对股价的影响是不可预测的。

column1: But, there are reasons to believe that higher interest rates, even though expected, can have a negative impact on home prices.
column2: 但人们却有理由相信较高的利率，即便在人们的预料之中，也能对房价产生负面影响。

column1: That is because home buyers are mostly ordinary people with little financial sophistication, unlike the professionals who trade in stocks.
column2: 这是因为与从事股票交易的专业人士不同，购房者大都是不谙金融之道的普通人。

column1: Untrained people with other things on their minds can make serious economic errors.
column2: 怀有其它顾虑的非专业人士可能会犯严重的经济错误。

column1: Home values have soared to high levels in many countries as irrational exuberance grips the markets.
column2: 由于市场被非理性的繁荣所控制，���多国家的房地产都已大幅增值。

column1: High home prices are already putting great stress on many families, which are struggling to make their mortgage payments.
column2: 高昂的房价已经给很多正艰难地偿还按揭贷款的家庭增加了巨大的压力。

column1: When interest rates go up, these payments will (when the rate is variable) also go up, possibly becoming unsustainable.
column2: 当利率增加时，还款额也会增加（在可变利率的情况下 ） ， 并可能变得难以负担。

column1: If one borrows the equivalent of three years' income to buy a house, a mortgage rate of 6% means that 18% of one's income goes to interest payments, which may be tolerable.
column2: 如果某人以6%的按揭利率贷了相当于其三年总收入的购房款，这就意味着其收入的18%将会用于偿还利息，这样的负担也许还能承受。

column1: But if the rate rises to 8%, mortgage interest payments rise to 24%, which, together with amortization, taxes, other debts, and necessary expenditures, may claim too much of the family budget.
column2: 但如果利率上升至8 % ， 按揭还款利息的比例就会上升到24 % ， 再加上分期付款、杂税、其它债务和必要支出，这样的负担可能就会超出一个家庭的还款能力。

column1: Some will then try to sell their overpriced homes, and the resulting market imbalance will cause prices to fall.
column2: 在此情况下，有些人可能就会出售其标价过高的住房，由此带来的市场不平衡就会导致房价下跌。

column1: People with fixed-rate mortgages are also vulnerable to rate increases, though less directly.
column2: 办理了固定利率按揭贷款的人同样容易受利率上升的影响，只不过这种影响不那么直接罢了。

column1: This is because if they have to move and sell their house, there may be no buyers who can afford higher interest payments, unless the home's price also falls.
column2: 这是因为如果他们不得不搬迁并出售住房，却可能没有买家能够负担得起更高的利息，除非房价也下跌。

column1: By contrast, sophisticated investors, such as big stock market players, are unlikely to fall prey to this trap.
column2: 相比之下，如股市大户一类的久经世故的投资者就不大容易跌入这样的陷阱。

column1: But homebuyers are not as savvy, so they may not see the change coming or they may fail to plan for it.
column2: 但购房者却没有那么精明，所以他们要么可能会发现不了即将到来的市场变化，要么可能会没有做好应对措施。

column1: As psychologists have shown, people are susceptible to "wishful thinking bias," wishing away possible future problems that they would rather not think about.
column2: 心理学家们指出许多人都容易罹患"妄想偏见 " ， 不愿设想自己所不愿考虑但却极可能发生的事。

column1: They may overemphasize the likelihood of economic success ("I will be making a lot more money in a few years") and underemphasize the commonplace problems that regularly challenge family budgets ("I will be losing my job or getting a divorce").
column2: 他们可能会过度强调经济成功的可能性 （ " 我会在未来几年赚很多钱 " ） 但却对时时威胁家庭预算的问题考虑不足 （ " 我会失业或离婚 " ） 。

column1: This blithe attitude is ultimately behind real estate bubbles where they are occurring.
column2: 正是这种盲目乐观的态度造成了房地产泡沫的出现。

column1: Low interest rates did not cause the bubbles.
column2: 低银行利率并没有造成泡沫。

column1: They only made it easier for people, in those areas of the world where there is a half-believable story about a fabulous future economy, to indulge their fantasies.
column2: 低利率只是让那些生活在经济前景仿佛一片光明的地区的人们更容易沉浸在他们的幻想之中。

column1: Interest rate increases will deliver a fresh dose of reality: the interest expense of owning a home is going to claim a larger share of family budgets, a hard fact that will eventually sink into our thinking.
column2: 利率的上升会让他们面对现实：购房的贷款利息将会占家庭预算的更大一部分，这是我们最终必须面对的严峻现实。

column1: But declines in home prices will not occur quickly when central banks begin to raise interest rates.
column2: 但房价下跌不会在各国央行开始调高利率之后很快出现。

column1: After two years of rate increases, Australia's home price boom only recently shows signs of abating.
column2: 在利率上升的两年之后，澳大利亚住房价格上涨的趋势才出现缓和迹象。

column1: Dominated by amateur investors, home markets do not turn on a dime.
column2: 在业余投资者的主导下，房屋市场对利率变化并不敏感。

column1: In places where home prices have been rising rapidly, the upward trend may continue or level off for a while.
column2: 在房价上涨过快的地方，这种上升趋势会在一段时间内保持或趋缓。

column1: In most high-priced places, a real decline may not come for some time.
column2: 在大多数高房价地区，真正的房价下跌可能要在相当一段时间之后才会出现。

column1: Will Russia Save the West?
column2: 俄国将会拯救西方？

column1: MOSCOW – Rapid changes in the global economy and international politics are raising, once more, an eternal issue in Russia: the country’s relations with Europe, and with the Euro-Atlantic region as a whole.
column2: 莫斯科 — — 全球经济与国际政治的快速变革，使得一个永恒的话题又一次在俄罗斯被人提起，这便是俄国与欧洲以及整个“欧洲-大西洋地区”之间的关系问题。

column1: Of course, Russia partly belongs to this region. Yet it cannot and does not want to join the West wholeheartedly – at least not yet.
column2: 当然，俄国也部分属于这一地区；但至少迄今为止，该国既无法、也不愿全心全意地加入西方。

column1: Meanwhile, this choice looks very different now compared to just a few years ago.
column2: 同时，与短短几年前相比，这一选择如今看上去已经发生了很大的改变。

column1: It is becoming obvious that the Euro-Atlantic world, whose economic and political model seemed so triumphant 20 years ago, is now lagging somewhat behind China and other Asian countries.
column2: 欧洲-大西洋世界的经济与政治模式在二十年前看上去大获成功，但它如今已稍稍落后于中国以及其他亚洲国家，这种颓势正变得日益明显。

column1: So is Russia, where, despite encouraging talk about innovation-based development, the economy continues to de-modernize as corruption has been allowed to metastasize, and as the country relies increasingly on its natural-resource wealth.
column2: 俄罗斯同样如此，尽管不乏鼓舞人心的言论（如建立在创新基础上的发展 ） ， 但随着贪腐弊病被允许向着各处蔓延、加上该国愈加依赖于自然资源这一财富，如今的俄罗斯经济之现代化程度正在继续下降。

column1: Indeed, it is Asia that has turned out to be the true winner of the Cold War.
column2: 的确，亚洲已证明自己才是冷战的真正胜利者。

column1: These rising powers raise problems regarding Russia’s geo-strategic choices.
column2: 这些崛起中的大国，为俄罗斯的地缘战略抉择带来了问题。

column1: For the first time in decades, the values gap between Russia and the EU appears to be increasing.
column2: 数十年来头一回，俄国与欧盟之间的价值隔阂看起来正在加大。

column1: Europe is overcoming state nationalism, while Russia is building a nation state.
column2: 欧洲正在克服国家民族主义，而俄罗斯却在构建一个民族国家。

column1: Broken by history and not wishing to be ravaged by war again, Europeans have embraced compromise and renounced the direct use of force in international relations.
column2: 为历史恩怨搅得身心俱疲、且不愿再受战争之苦的欧洲人，已经接受了妥协这种方式，并放弃了在国际关系中对武力的直接使用。

column1: Russians, on the other hand, emphasize their “hard power,” including military force, because they know that they live in a dangerous world and have no one to hide behind.
column2: 而俄国人正好相反，他们继续强调包括军事力量在内的“硬实力 ” ， 因为他们明白：自己身处一个危机四伏的世界之中，且没有靠山可供求助。

column1: And, because of the country’s comparative lack of “soft power” – social, cultural, and economic attractiveness – it stands ready to use the competitive advantages (i.e., its resource wealth) available to it.
column2: 而且，由于该国社会、文化以及经济方面的吸引力等“软实力”相对缺乏，它只得做好准备，将其竞争力高的现有优势（比如其资源领域的财富）加以应用。

column1: Internal political developments in Russia are also pushing the country in a different direction from the West.
column2: 俄国国内政治的发展也使该国与西方渐行渐远。

column1: Quite simply, Russia is moving away from democracy.
column2: 道理很简单，俄罗斯正在远离民主制度。

column1: This emerging values gap is not an insurmountable obstacle to geostrategic rapprochement.
column2: 对于地缘战略层面的和解而言，这一逐步浮现的价值隔阂并非一道不可逾越的鸿沟。

column1: But, coupled with mutual irritation, which is particularly strong in Russia, closing the gap is becoming much harder.
column2: 但与之相伴的还有俄国与西方的相互刺激（这一点在俄国尤为强烈 ） ， 这使得消除隔阂的难度增大了许多。

column1: For, while Russia’s elite never considered itself defeated in the Cold War, the West essentially treated Russia as a defeated country – an attitude symbolized by NATO’s eastward expansion, which laid a deep foundation for ongoing tension.
column2: 因为尽管俄国精英从未认为自己在冷战中落败，但西方的做法从本质上说，就是在以对待战败国的方式对待俄罗斯；而北约东扩便是这种态度的典型表现，这一做法为目前的紧张状态埋下了很深的伏笔。

column1: It was only after the West encountered an armed rebuff in South Ossetia that NATO expansion was stopped in its tracks.
column2: 直到西方在南奥赛梯地区遭遇到武力抵制之后，北约东扩的脚步方才停下。

column1: Yet NATO has not given up on further enlargement.
column2: 然而，北约仍未放弃进一步的扩张。

column1: NATO expansion is nothing more than the extension of its zone of influence – and in the most sensitive, military-political sphere.
column2: 北约东扩其实就是自身势力范围的扩张（这还是在最为敏感的军事与政治领域 ） 。

column1: And yet the West’s unwillingness to abandon that effort is coupled with a repeated refusal to recognize Russia’s right to have its own zone of interest.
column2: 而且西方在不愿放弃扩张努力的同时，还三番五次地拒绝承认俄罗斯也有获得其自身利益范围的权利。

column1: So NATO expansion has left the Cold War unfinished. The ideological and military confrontation that underlay it is gone, but the geopolitical rivalry that it entailed has returned to the fore.
column2: 因此，北约东扩使得冷战仍未结束；作为冷战基础的意识形态与军事对抗已然不见踪影，但随之而来的地缘政治竞争却重返舞台中央。

column1: Thus, the old mentality survived on both sides.
column2: 这样，传统思维在俄国与西方都重现生机。

column1: Energy debates are another example of this.
column2: 能源争论则是另一个例证。

column1: Non-Russian Europe should thank the Almighty for the presence of energy-rich Russia at its borders, while Russia should be thankful for having such wealthy customers.
column2: 俄国以外的欧洲应该感谢上帝，因为后者安排能源丰富的俄罗斯与它为邻；而俄国也应为拥有这样一批富有的主顾而心存感激。

column1: But the natural differences in the interests of energy consumers and producers have been given a political/security twist – witness the discussions about an “Energy NATO.”
column2: 但能源消费者与生产者之间利益的天然分歧，又被打上了政治与安全方面的色彩，于是便出现了关于“能源北约”的讨论。

column1: Faced with the impossibility of advantageous accession to Euro-Atlantic institutions, Russia is drifting fast towards alignment with China – a “younger brother,” though a respected one.
column2: 俄国在眼见无望以有利条件加入欧洲-大西洋机制后，便向着与中国这个“小兄弟 ” （ 不过却是一个令人敬重的后辈）结盟的方向快速转变。

column1: Russia’s “Asian choice” of today is not the same as the Slavophile/Eurasian choice of the past.
column2: 如今，俄国的“亚洲选择”已不同于往日那种斯拉夫主义/欧亚主义之选择。

column1: On the surface, it looks like a choice in favor of a rapidly rising civilization. But the current estrangement from Europe – the cradle of Russian civilization and modernization – threatens Russia’s identity and will increase its geostrategic risks in the future.
column2: 从表面上看，这似乎是一个有利于快速崛起之文明的选择，但当前俄国与欧洲（这是俄国文明与现代化的摇篮）的疏离，却对前者的身份产生了威胁，并会增加其未来的地缘战略风险。

column1: Europe does not benefit from this estrangement either.
It will continue to move towards beautiful decay – Venice writ large.
The United States also loses. Without Russia, which will remain the world’s third strongest power for the foreseeable future, it is impossible to solve the key problems of international security.
column2: 欧洲也不会从这一疏离中获益，它将继续其优雅的衰败过程 — — 威尼斯便是很好的例子；美国同样未能幸免，它若失去了在可预见的未来中、继续身为全球第三强国的俄罗斯之协助，也将无法解决国际安全领域的关键问题。

column1: The current Euro-Atlantic security architecture seems to suit the majority of Americans and Europeans, though it is becoming increasingly fragile and counterproductive.So Russia will struggle to create a new architecture largely on its own – whether through a new treaty on collective European security, or even through its accession to NATO.
column2: 当前的欧洲-大西洋安全体系，尽管正变得日渐脆弱，其效果也愈加事与愿违，但看起来它却仍令大部分美欧人士中意。 因此，俄罗斯将主要依靠自己的力量，努力创建出一个新的体系 — — 无论是通过欧洲集体安全方面的新条约，还是甚至通过加入北约。

column1: This is not only in Russian political and civilizational interest, but it also reflects our duty to the entire community of Euro-Atlantic nations, which is being weakened by the “unfinished Cold War.”
column2: 这不单符合俄国的政治与文明利益，也反映出我们对于整个欧洲-大西洋诸国共同体的义务，后者正被“尚未完结的冷战”所削弱。

column1: The idea of a “Union of Europe” between Russia and the EU should be put on the long-term agenda.
column2: 而在俄国与欧盟之间建立一个“欧洲联合体”的设想，也应被列入长期日程安排之中。

column1: That Union should be based on a common human, economic, and energy space.
column2: 这一联合体应当建立在共同的人员、经济与能源范围基础之上。

column1: The combination of a new security arrangement for the Euro-Atlantic community and the establishment of the Union of Europe could arrest the decline in the international weight of the West.
column2: 在欧洲-大西洋共同体的新型安全制度、以及欧洲联合体的建立这两大因素的共同作用之下，西方国际影响力的下滑趋势将得以终止。

column1: Will Success Spoil Brazil?
column2: 成功会不会让巴西骄纵？

column1: RIO DE JANEIRO – Brazil has been making international headlines of late, but not for traditional stories about urban violence, natural catastrophes, political corruption, or deforestation in the Amazon.
column2: 巴西最近登上了国际新闻的头版头条，但却不是因为城市暴力、自然灾害、政治腐败或亚马逊地区森林砍伐等传统的报导。

column1: At the G-20 Summit in London last April, for example, US President Barack Obama called for the world to pay heed to Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the “most popular politician on earth,” and shook hands with him, saying: “My man right here.
column2: 去年4月召开的伦敦二十国峰会上，美国总统巴拉克·奥巴马呼吁世界关注巴西总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦，称他为“地球上最受欢迎的政治家 ” ， 奥巴马同达席尔瓦握手，说 ： “ 这是我的偶像。

column1: I love this guy.”
column2: 我爱他 。 ”

column1: In September, the ousted president of Honduras, Manuel Zelaya, reappeared in the country inside the Brazilian embassy in Tegucigalpa after three months of exile.
column2: 9月，遭到驱逐的洪都拉斯总统曼努埃尔·塞拉亚在经历了三个月的流亡生活后在巴西驻特古西加尔巴大使馆再度露面。

column1: Although his presence dramatically fuelled the situation for a time, Brazilian diplomats, working with the US, were able to reach agreement with Honduran authorities to allow Manuel Zelaya to return to office.
column2: 虽然他的现身一度给本已混乱的局势火上浇油，但巴西外交人员与美国合作，成功地与洪都拉斯当局达成协议，允许曼努埃尔·塞拉亚重新执政。

column1: Then came the news that Brazil will host the 2016 Summer Olympic Games – this coming on top of hosting the 2014 World Cup.
column2: 随后传来消息说2016年夏季奥运会将在巴西举办 — — 巴西也同样是2014年世界杯的主办国。

column1: As for the global – and fortunately now abating – economic crisis, Brazil has shined throughout, recording a fast and strong recovery.
column2: 在正在趋于缓和的全球经济危机中，巴西自始至终一直表现出色，出现了快速强劲的经济复苏。

column1: And, as if this good news were not enough, Brazil’s giant state oil company, Petrobrás, is already at work developing two huge deep-water oil fields discovered in the sea off the coast of Rio de Janeiro.
column2: 这还不算，巴西的巨型国家石油企业巴西石油公司（Petrobrás）已经着手实施沿里约热内卢海岸线发现的两块巨型深水油田的开发工作。

column1: For these and other reasons, Brazil is gaining the world’s attention.
column2: 上述以及其它原因让巴西受到世界的瞩目。

column1: Brazilian democracy, at long last, is working well, following many years of military government, and its economy seems more robust than ever.
column2: 巴西的民主制度在历经多年的军政府统治后，终于得以修成正果，巴西经济也比以往任何时刻更加繁荣。

column1: As a result, many people are enthusiastically pointing to an increased international role for Brazil in the future.
column2: 因此，许多人热情地指出巴西将在未来发挥更大的国际作用。

column1: But two connected and major challenges lie ahead for Brazil and its government: the need to build a far more equal society and to resist the temptation to use nationalism to mask whatever domestic failures may manifest themselves.
column2: 但巴西及其政府面临着两项相互关联的重大挑战：建设更为平等的社会，以及经受住利用民族主义掩盖任何国内失败的诱惑。

column1: Brazil’s current success is rooted not only in Lula’s two terms, which must end in 2010.
column2: 不仅是必须在2010年结束两届任期的卢拉造就了巴西目前的成功。

column1: The economic stabilization program enacted by Fernando Henrique Cardoso since 1994 (the Real Plan), first as finance minister and then as president for two terms, solidified a structure that made it possible for Lula’s tenure to be so prosperous.
column2: 1994年来先任财政部长再任两届总统的费尔南多·恩里克·卡多佐推行的经济稳定计划（即雷亚尔计划）奠定了坚实的结构性基础，使得卢拉在其任期内有可能实现经济繁荣。

column1: This is not meant to take anything away from Lula.
column2: 但这丝毫也不能抹杀卢拉的贡献。

column1: His presidency has guaranteed political stability and strengthened social cohesion.
column2: 他在总统任期内保障了政治稳定，加强了社会凝聚力。

column1: Indeed, by managing the political process to make the government work for Brazil’s people, Lula’s administration has made Brazil a truly stable and consensual democracy.
column2: 事实上，卢拉内阁通过管理政治程序实现了政府为巴西人民服务，并使巴西成为真正稳定团结的民主国家。

column1: There is nothing modest about that achievement, given Brazil’s traditional institutional instability and the series of major corruption scandals that engulfed Lula’s government in 2005 and 2006.
column2: 考虑到一直困扰着巴西的制度动荡和2005、2006年几乎吞噬卢拉政府的系列重大腐败丑闻，这一成绩的取得绝非易事。

column1: Lula survived those scandals and did not move to amend the constitution in order to seek a third term, though some in Brazil pressed him to do so.
column2: 卢拉在那场丑闻中幸免于难，而且也顶住了来自巴西某些势力的压力，并未修改宪法谋求第三次连任。

column1: Lula also enacted critically important social policies.
column2: 卢拉还推行了至关重要的社会政策。

column1: Under his government, two million homes received electric power for the first time, 11 million very poor families gained the support of a minimum income (the Bolsa Família), the minimum salary grew 45% in real terms, thus benefiting 42 million people.
column2: 在以他为首的政府领导下，有两百万家庭首次用上了电，一千一百万极端贫困家庭获得了最低工资补助（家庭补助金计划 ） ， 最低薪酬按实值计算增长了45 % ， 并因此惠及了四千二百万民众。

column1: Moreover, eight million jobs were created, 17 million people escaped poverty, and the income of the poorest 50% grew 32% – twice as fast as the income of the richest 10% in the same period.
column2: 此外，政府还创造了八百万个就业岗位，帮助一千七百万人实现脱贫，最贫困的半数人口收入增长了32 % — —这一比率相当于同时期10%最富裕人口收入增长速度的两倍。

column1: And Lula achieved all this without triggering inflation, which he knows – perhaps a result of his own impoverished childhood – wreaks havoc on the poor most of all.
column2: 卢拉在不引发通胀的前提下实现了上述所有目标，因为他知道 — — 这或许来自于他本人贫困的童年经历 — — 通胀带给穷人的灾难最为深重。

column1: This vast transformation has not only generated a virtuous circle that strengthened institutional stability and social capital. It has also differentiated Brazil from other countries in Latin America, putting the country in the forefront in the region in terms of dealing with traditional social and economic injustices in a democratic way.
column2: 如此巨大的转变不仅创造了强化制度稳定和社会资本的良性循环，同时也让巴西从诸多南美国家之中脱颖而出，使其站在了拉美地区以民主方式应对传统社会和经济不平等现象的最前沿领域。

column1: Yet the remaining challenges are huge, for Brazil remains the seventh most unequal society in the world – and severe violence persists.
column2: 但余下的挑战也非常巨大，因为巴西仍然是世界第七大最不平等社会 — — 仍然存在着严重的暴力冲突。

column1: Sixty-four percent of Brazilian homes lack electricity and sanitation, and only 22% have electricity, a telephone, a computer, a refrigerator, a television, and a washing machine.
column2: 百分之六十四的巴西家庭缺少电和卫生设备，只有22%的家庭能用上电、电话、电脑、冰箱、电视和洗衣机。

column1: In the poorest region, the North and Northeast, the numbers fall to 8.6% and 8.3%.
column2: 在最贫困的北部和东北部地区，这一数字下降到8.6%和8.3 % 。

column1: Among the young, almost 37% of 18-24-year-olds do not finish high school.
column2: 有几乎37%的18到24岁的年轻人没有念完高中。

column1: Only half the population over age 25 has more than eight years of formal education.
column2: 25岁以上人口中只有半数接受过8年以上的正规教育。

column1: As for Brazil’s international role, a subtle competition is emerging with the US.
column2: 巴西在国际作用领域正在同美国进行着微妙的竞争。

column1: America wants to conclude as many free-trade agreements in the region as it can, while Brazil favors expanding its custom union, Mercosul/Mercosur.
column2: 美国希望能在区域内尽可能多的签订自由贸易协议，而巴西则更愿意进一步拓展其关税联盟和南方共同市场（Mercosul/Mercosur ） 。

column1: The entrance of Venezuela into the Brazilian bloc, Brazilian leadership at the United Nations mission in Haiti, and Brazil’s role in the Honduran affair are all part of this emerging competition.
column2: 委内瑞拉加入巴西集团、巴西人领导联合国的海地维和行动、以及巴西在洪都拉斯问题上所起的作用都构成了这种正在形成的竞争关系。

column1: If Brazil is to remain on its prosperous path, it must continue to give higher priority to its social and economic programs than to foreign adventures.
column2: 如果巴西想在繁荣大道上走得更远，就必须继续给予社会和经济计划比外资企业更多的支持。

column1: The construction of a major egalitarian, free, and democratic society that respects and works with the international institutions is the best thing that Brazil can give to the world right now.
column2: 建设尊重国际体系并与之合作的平等、自由和民主的社会是巴西能够献给世界的最好的礼物。

column1: Will Technology Kill Convergence?
column2: 技术会扼杀趋同吗？

column1: WASHINGTON, DC – At last week’s annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Lima, Peru, one topic that dominated discussions was the slowdown in emerging-economy growth.
column2: 华盛顿—在上周世界银行和国际货币基金组织（IMF）在秘鲁利马举行的年会上，一个主导了讨论过程的话题是新兴经济体增长放缓。

column1: Hailed in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis as the new engines of the world economy, the emerging economies are now acting as a drag on global growth, and many argue that their era of rapid expansion – and their quest to achieve convergence with advanced-country income levels – is over.
column2: 2008年金融危机爆发后，新兴经济体被誉为世界经济体的新增长引擎，但如今，新兴经济体成了全球增长的拖累因素，许多人认为，它们的快速扩张期已经结束，它们对实现向发达国家收入水平趋同的努力也已经结束。

column1: Are the doomsayers right?
column2: 这些末日论者说得对吗？

column1: There is certainly reason for concern – beginning in China.
column2: 当然，担忧的理由是存在的 — — 从中国开始。

column1: After decades of nearly double-digit growth, China appears to be experiencing a marked slowdown – one that some argue is actually worse than official statistics indicate.
column2: 在经历了几十年的近两位数的增长后，中国似乎开始经历显著放缓 — — 有人认为放缓幅度之大实际比官方统计数字更加糟糕。

column1: As China’s growth slows, so does its demand for oil and commodities, with severe effects for other emerging economies that depend on commodity exports.
column2: 随着中国增长的放缓，其对石油和大宗商品的需求也放缓了，这给其他依赖大宗商品出口的新兴经济体造成了严重影响。

column1: Moreover, the benefits of lower commodity prices do not seem to have materialized among net importers, except perhaps India; if they have, they have been far from adequate to offset other growth-damaging forces.
column2: 此外，大宗商品价格下跌的好处并没有体现在净出口国身上（也许印度是个例外 ） ， 即使获得了好处，也远不足以抵消其他不利于增长的力量。

column1: Meanwhile, the advanced economies are tentatively recovering from the 2008 crisis.
column2: 与此同时，发达经济体正在从2008年的危机小心翼翼地复苏。

column1: As a result, the differential between growth in the emerging and advanced economies – aggregated from IMF data, and including Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan in the emerging group – has declined considerably.
column2: 结果，新兴和发达经济体之间的增长差异 — — 据IMF数据加总，香港、新加坡、韩国和台湾被归为新兴经济体组 — — 显著收缩。

column1: Indeed, after averaging three percentage points for two decades and rising to 4.8 percentage points in 2010, the percentage-point differential fell to 2.5 last year and is expected to amount to just 1.5 this year.
column2: 事实上，二十年来，这一差异平均值为三个百分点，2010年上升到4.8个百分点，去年下降到2.5个百分点，今年预计将继续下降到1.5个百分点。

column1: The question, then, is whether the growth differential will remain as low at it is today.
column2: 因此，问题是这一增长差异是否会保持在今天那么低的水平。

column1: Those who believe that it will, typically rely on three arguments, all of which require some qualification.
column2: 相信答案是肯定的人通常基于三个原因，这三个原因都值得商榷。

column1: First, they argue that much convergence has already taken place in manufacturing.
column2: 首先，他们认为趋同的大部分发生在制造业。

column1: This is true, but it neglects the increasing interconnectedness of manufacturing and services, and the changing nature of many services.
column2: 确实如此，但他们忽视了制造业和服务业日益互通的趋势和许多服务业性质的变化。

column1: An iPad, for example, must not just be built; it also needs coding services.
column2: 比如，一个iPad不仅仅包括制造过程，还需要编程服务。

column1: In a sense, it is actually more the product of the modern services sector than of manufacturing.
column2: 从某种程度讲，iPad实际上更多地是现代服务业产品，而不是制造品。

column1: And there are plenty of untapped opportunities for technological catch-up in, say, health, education, and financial services.
column2: 而在（比如）医疗、教育和金融服务方面，有大量技术赶超机会等待新兴市场去把握。

column1: Second, emerging-market bears point out that these economies have gained major productivity benefits from the migration of surplus rural labor to urban areas, a surplus that will soon be exhausted.
column2: 其次，新兴市场悲观派指出，这些经济体生产率大提高主要来自农村剩余劳动力向城镇的迁移，而这一剩余劳动力很快就会耗尽。

column1: This, too, is true.
column2: 的确如此。

column1: But it ignores the fact that there still is a huge reservoir of urban labor in the informal sector that, upon shifting to the formal sector, would provide an additional boost to productivity.
column2: 但它忽视了一个事实：非正式部门仍存在巨大的城镇劳动力储备，只要他们进入正式部门，就能带来新的生产率刺激。

column1: The pessimists’ third argument is that emerging economies are not implementing fast enough the structural reforms needed to support long-term growth.
column2: 悲观者的第三个观点是新兴经济体实施支持长期增长所需要的结构改革的步伐不够快。

column1: Again, there is some truth to this argument: structural reforms are needed everywhere.
column2: 这一论点也有些道理：结构改革哪里都需要。

column1: But there is no proven way to measure the pace of their implementation.
column2: 但没有经受过检验的方法可用于衡量结构改革实施的节奏。

column1: As a result, it is difficult to argue that the emerging economies have collectively slowed in their structural-reform efforts.
column2: 因此，很难认为新兴市场在结构改革方面集体滞后了。

column1: But there may be a fourth mechanism at work, related to the changing – and seriously disruptive – nature of new technologies.
column2: 但也许还有第四个因素在起作用，即新技术的多变性 — — 以及严重的破坏性。

column1: A major driver of past catch-up, if only in terms of incremental growth, was the shift of many activities in both the services and manufacturing sectors from advanced economies to developing countries with lower wages.
column2: 在过去，赶超的一大动力 — — 如果用增量增长衡量的话 — — 是服务业和制造业的许多活动从发达经济体转移到低工资的发展中国家。

column1: Now, however, a growing array of activities can be automated.
column2: 但是，如今，越来越多的这些活动可以自动化。

column1: And coding-supported products often have lower costs per unit of output than even very cheap labor can provide.
column2: 代码支持的产品的单位产出成本通常比极低价劳动力所能提供的还要低。

column1: So, whereas call centers, for example, used to be mostly staffed in low-wage countries, now the computer-robot that does most of the talking can be located in New York.
column2: 因此，尽管（比如）呼叫中心大多在低工资国家运行，但如今，用电脑机器人进行大部分对话的呼叫中心也可以坐落在纽约。

column1: That observation should not, however, overshadow fundamental economic insights – specifically, that trade and the location of production are determined by comparative, not absolute, advantage.
column2: 但是，这一观察无法压倒基本经济学洞见 — — 具体而言，就是贸易和生产地由比较优势而非绝对优势决定。

column1: A country will always have a comparative advantage in something; but that something changes.
column2: 一国总会在某些方面拥有比较优势；但“某些方面”是会变化的。

column1: Many advanced countries, for example, now have a comparative advantage in high-value-added activities.
column2: 比如，许多发达国家现在的比较优势是高增加值活动。

column1: In other words, thanks to their highly skilled labor forces, they are better equipped than their developing-country counterparts for activities like the production of made-to-measure specialized goods or, indeed, anything that requires a highly trained team to work in close proximity.
column2: 换句话说，由于它们拥有高技能劳动力，因此比发展中国家更适合生产定制专业化产品或一切需要受过良好训练的团队紧密合作的活动。

column1: But the technology-induced shifts that are underway could portend big disruptions in global value chains – disruptions affecting both developed and developing countries.
column2: 但技术导致的正在发生的变迁可能预示着全球价值链的大幅扰动 — — 这些扰动既影响发达国家，也影响发展中国家。

column1: In fact, we may have entered a period of fundamental change that could weaken growth everywhere, as the “old” shrinks before the “new” can occupy sufficient space.
column2: 事实上，我们可能已经进入了一个根本性变革时代 ， “ 旧”东西已经破坏而“新”东西尚未占据足够大的空间，所有国家的增长率都可能遭到削弱。

column1: To be sure, the creative destruction that is taking place seems to be affecting developing-economy growth proportionately more than advanced-economy growth, largely because the new technologies are being put to work where they were invented, and developing countries have not yet managed sufficient imitation.
column2: 平心而论，正在发生的创造性破坏对发展中经济体的影响似乎相对来说大于发达经济体，这主要是因为，新技术正在发明它们的地方启用，而发展中国家尚无法进行足够的模仿。

column1: But I am not convinced that “catch-up” opportunities will remain diminished – not least because it will always be easier to imitate than to invent.
column2: 但我不确定“赶超”机会会一直减少下去 — — 因为模仿总是比发明容易。

column1: In fact, it could be argued that new “leap-frogging” may become possible.
column2: 事实上，可以说，新的“蛙跳”会成为可能。

column1: As experience in the telecommunications sector shows, the ability to adopt new technologies without first having to dismantle old systems can enable rapid progress.
column2: 通讯业的经验表明，在不必破坏旧体系的情况下采取新技术的能力可以带来快速进步。

column1: The key to enabling continued convergence – even at a fairly rapid pace – is good political governance.
column2: （甚至以相当快的速度）带来持续趋同的关键是良好的政治治理。

column1: Developing-country governments must implement policies aimed at managing the impending transformation, while maintaining social solidarity and cohesion.
column2: 发展中国家政府必须实施旨在管理即将到来的转型的政策，同时保持社会团结和凝聚。

column1: That is the challenge they must meet at this time of great disruption.
column2: 这是它们在大干扰时代所必须面对的挑战。

column1: Will the EU Keep Faith with Turkey?
column2: 欧盟会兑现对土耳其的承诺吗？

column1: EMBARGO 6 SEPTEMBER 2004
column2: 2004 年 9 月 ， 6 号禁令

column1: More than forty years ago, Turkey applied for associate membership of the European Economic Community.
column2: 四十多年前，土耳其申请了欧共体候补成员。

column1: With the Association agreement of 1963, a special relationship was established, culminating in the customs union of 1996.
column2: 双方的特殊关系从1963年签订候补协议时开始，并于1996年订立关税联盟时达到了高潮。

column1: During all these years, European governments consistently confirmed Turkey's eligibility for full membership, making accession dependent on compliance with membership criteria.
column2: 这些年来，欧洲政府一直承认土耳其的完全会员资格，条件是土耳其要遵守成员国的行为准则。

column1: Turkey's formal recognition as a candidate state in 1999 led Turkey to undertake unprecedented reform efforts in the area of human and minority rights, including abolition of the death penalty, safeguards against torture, promotion of religious freedoms, gender equality, and restriction of the military's role in political life.
column2: 1999年正式承认候补资格后，土耳其在人权和少数民族权利领域开始了前所未有的改革，包括取消死刑、反对酷刑、推动宗教自由、性别平等和限制军队在政治生活中的作用。

column1: Should the EU consider the accession criteria as having been fulfilled, it must decide to open negotiations in early 2005.
column2: 如果欧盟认为达到了准入条件，就必须在2005年初开始谈判。

column1: Not to do so would mean to renege on political commitments and to severely damage the EU's credibility in the world.
column2: 不这么做就意味着不履行政治承诺，会严重损害欧盟的国际信誉。

column1: In many parts of Europe, however, Turkey's admission to the EU is viewed with skepticism owing to its size, relatively poor economy, fears of massive immigration, and, above all, cultural and societal differences - a euphemism for Islam. It would be foolish to deny that some of these factors represent serious challenges.
column2: 但欧洲许多国家都对土耳其的加入持怀疑态度，因为它疆域辽阔、经济也欠发达，他们害怕土耳其进入欧盟会引发大规模移民潮，更重要的是，土耳其与欧洲国家存在着文化和社会方面的巨大差异－说得再直接点，土耳其是个伊斯兰国家。

column1: However, they are often exaggerated and certainly not insurmountable.
column2: 否认这些因素会带来挑战是愚蠢的，但也不能过分夸大，甚至夸大到无法克服。

column1: Negotiations with Turkey would be lengthy and accession may not occur before 2015.
column2: 与土耳其的谈判过程也许会很漫长，2015年前也可能不会有结果。

column1: This period of time would offer both Turkey and the Union an opportunity to come to terms.
column2: 但这段时间却给了土耳其和欧盟机会进行自我调整，以便最终达到要求。

column1: With 80 million people, Turkey would be one of the largest EU states.
column2: 有着8000万人口，土耳其会是欧盟最大的国家之一。

column1: But the size of a country plays only a limited role in the EU's decision-making process, because political influence within the Union depends more on economic power.
column2: 但在欧盟的决策过程中，国家的大小起不了决定作用，因为欧盟内部的政治影响更多地取决于经济方面的实力。

column1: Moreover, for decades Turkey has been a responsible member of many European institutions, and there is no reason to believe that it would act differently in the EU.
column2: 此外，几十年来，土耳其一直是很多欧洲机构最忠实的成员，我们没有理由相信加入欧盟会改变这一切。

column1: Because of its weak economy, Turkey would be eligible for substantial EU assistance.
column2: 因为经济欠发达，土耳其会得到欧盟的大量援助。

column1: The size of these transfers, however, would depend on the EU's financial policies at the time of admission, the outcome of accession negotiations, and economic developments in Turkey.
column2: 但拨款的具体数额要看欧盟当时的金融政策、进入谈判的结果和土耳其自身的经济状况。

column1: In any case, the EU's practice of "capping" its budget would prevent an explosion in the financial costs entailed by Turkey's accession.
column2: 不管怎样，欧盟的财政限额政策会防止土耳其加入带来的财政开支大幅增长。

column1: Immigration should not be a cause for undue concern, either.
column2: 移民问题也无须引起过多的担心。

column1: Human mobility is limited, and Turkey workers' would probably be allowed to move freely within the EU only after a long transition period, possibly not before 2025.
column2: 人员流动是有限的，而且土耳其劳工只有在很长的过渡期后才可以在欧洲自由流动，这种过渡可能一直延续到2025年。

column1: Given the expected upswing of Turkey's economy and its declining birthrate, experts predict a figure of around 2.7 million immigrants by that point.
column2: 考虑到土耳其的经济发展和出生率下降，专家预计届时的移民数量可能在270万人。

column1: Meanwhile, diminishing and aging populations in most of Europe will have made immigration a necessity.
column2: 与此同时，欧洲多数国家人口数量的减少和年龄的老化有必要依靠移民来补充。

column1: Among the countries from where immigration to the EU is probable, Turkey has the best prospects for successful adaptation.
column2: 可能移民到欧盟的国家中，土耳其人最有可能融合成功。

column1: It is Turkey's Muslim population that creates the strongest emotions.
column2: 但激起最强烈反对的是土耳其的穆斯林们。

column1: Many feel that Turkey simply does not fit into a European society based on Christian traditions and culture.
column2: 很多人认为土耳其根本不可能融入建立在基督教传统和文化基础上的欧洲社会。

column1: It is also feared that Islamists may one day turn Turkey into a fundamentalist state.
column2: 人们害怕有一天，伊斯兰份子会把土耳其变成原教旨主义国家。

column1: Unlikely as it may be in view of Turkey's deeply rooted secularism, such a risk cannot be totally excluded.
column2: 虽然根深蒂固的世俗主义使这种转变不太可能发生，但毕竟不能完全排除这样的危险。

column1: But the same is true for any other democracy, where radical groups could well misuse the democratic process for their purposes.
column2: 但反过来想想，其它民主社会也有同样的问题，激进组织完全可能利用民主进程为自己的目标服务。

column1: Surely, the best protection against such a calamity is to strengthen Turkey's democratic system, which can best be achieved by anchoring it firmly in a bloc of similarly democratic countries.
column2: 当然，对这种灾难的最好保护是加强土耳其的民主系统，而最好的办法就是让它在类似的民主国家中深深地扎根。

column1: As for the EU, it must decide whether it wants to be a closed "Christian club" or an open and inclusive society, drawing strength from cultural and religious diversity.
column2: 至于欧盟，它必须选择想成为封闭的"基督教俱乐部 " ， 还是开放、包容的社会，从文化和宗教的多元性中汲取力量。

column1: Turkey's accession to the Union would give a powerful answer, one that would be heard with particular clarity in the Islamic world.
column2: 土耳其加入欧盟会做出有力的回答，伊斯兰世界会更清楚地感受到这种影响。

column1: The need to refute arguments against Turkey's admission to the EU leaves the advantages rarely mentioned: its unique geopolitical position at the crossroads of the Balkans, Southern Caucasus, Central Asia, and the Middle East - vitally important regions for Europe's security; its role as mayor transit country for energy supplies; its military capabilities at a time when the EU is developing its new European Defense Policy; and the great potential of the Turkish economy, with its young and dynamic labor force.
column2: 对反对土耳其入盟论调的驳斥常常使人们忽略了它真正的优势：它地处巴尔干、南高加索、中亚和中东交叉点的独特地理位置－这些地区都对欧洲安全起着至关重要的作用；它还是能源供应的中转站；欧盟制定新欧洲防卫政策时也要借助土耳其的军事力量；土耳其的经济潜力巨大，劳动力年轻、充满活力。

column1: At the same time, the risks of rejecting Turkey must also be taken into account: the likelihood that the reform process would collapse, bringing radical currents to the fore and leading to instability and political unrest at the EU's doorsteps.
column2: 与此同时，也必须考虑拒绝土耳其的危险：改革进程可能半途而废、极端势力可能走到前台，在欧洲大门口造成局势不稳和政治动荡。

column1: Turkish EU membership presents both opportunities and challenges.
column2: 土耳其成为欧盟成员既是机遇、又是挑战。

column1: On balance, however, the advantages far outweigh the risks.
column2: 但权衡利弊，利益会远远超过风险。

column1: Will the Euro Dethrone the Dollar?
column2: 欧元会取代美元的位置吗？

column1: Much of America’s dominance in world finance comes from the dollar’s status as international money.
column2: 美国在世界金融中的霸主地位很大一部分来自于美元作为国际货币的地位。

column1: America’s commitment to free capital markets, the rule of law, and price stability confer credibility on the dollar as a store of value.
column2: 美国对自由的资本市场、法治以及价格稳定的承诺带给美元作为价值储备的可信度。

column1: But American spending habits have undermined the dollar’s reputation, with the excess supply of dollars on world markets depressing its price.
column2: 但是，美国人的消费习惯破坏了美元的声誉，而美元在世界市场上的过度供应又压抑了它的价格。

column1: This spring, the euro’s exchange rate against the dollar reached an all-time high, and central banks have increased the euro share of their international reserves.
column2: 今年春天，欧元与美元的汇率达到了历史新高，各国的中央银行也增加了欧元在其国际储备中的份额。

column1: Is the dollar about to lose the crown of world finance to the euro?
column2: 美元是否要将世界金融的皇冠拱手让给欧元呢？

column1: History suggests otherwise, despite a vulnerable dollar.
column2: 历史表明，尽管美元软弱，但是情况还是相反。

column1: American financial supremacy in the twenty-first century resembles Britain’s position in world finance a century ago.
column2: 美国在二十一世纪的金融霸主地位和英国在一个世纪前的地位相似。

column1: Before the outbreak of World War I in August 1914, the pound sterling served as the currency of choice for international transactions, just as the dollar does today, and the world’s borrowers visited the City of London to raise capital.
column2: 在1914年8月第一次世界大战爆发之前，英镑正如当今的美元一样是国际交易的首选货币，全世界的借款者都造访伦敦时来筹集资本。

column1: The British economist John Maynard Keynes worried that countries would not use sterling to settle trading balances with each other if the pound were not viewed as a reliable store of value.
column2: 英国经济学家凯恩斯担心，如果人们不把英镑看作可靠的价值储备，那么，各国就不会用英镑来结算各自的交易结余。

column1: The “future position of the City of London,” according to Keynes, depended on the pound sterling continuing to serve the business world as the equivalent of gold.
column2: 凯恩斯认为 ， “ 伦敦市的未来地位”取决于英镑继续作为黄金的等价物为工商界服务。

column1: Britain maintained the pound’s convertibility into gold at the outbreak of the Great War to preserve its credibility as the international medium of exchange.
column2: 英国在第一次世界大战爆发之际维持英镑可兑换为黄金来维持其国际交易媒介的信誉。

column1: The dollar could not challenge sterling’s role as the world’s currency without matching its reputation.
column2: 美元不追赶上英镑的声誉就无法挑战英镑世界货币的作用。

column1: August 1914 provided the opportunity.
column2: 1914年8月提供了这样的一个机遇。

column1: The biggest gold outflow in a generation imperiled America’s ability to repay its debts abroad.
column2: 在整整一代人中最大的一次黄金外流破坏了美国偿还海外债务的能力。

column1: Fear that the US would abandon the gold standard sent the dollar plummeting on world markets.
column2: 人们担心美国将会放弃金本位制，美元在世界市场上暴跌。

column1: But Treasury Secretary William G. McAdoo secured American financial honor in August 1914 by remaining true to gold while everyone else, except for the British, abandoned their obligations.
column2: 但是，正当除了英国以外的其他所有国家都放弃其义务之际，美国财政部长麦克阿杜在1914年8月坚持金本位不变，从而为美国赢得了金融信誉。

column1: Despite the dollar’s instant credibility, however, it took more than a decade for America’s currency to match Britain’s as an international medium of exchange.
column2: 但是，尽管美元声誉日隆，美国货币追赶上英镑作为国际交易媒介还是花了十年多的时间。

column1: Payment habits melt at a glacier’s pace.
column2: 支付习惯改变决非一朝一夕。

column1: Britain’s transformation from international creditor to international debtor during the Great War gave the dollar a second wind in its battle with sterling.
column2: 英国在第一次世界大战中从国际债权人沦为国际债务人，从而给了美元在与英镑的较量中的第二次生机。

column1: The British were forced to abandon gold convertibility in April 1919 – a tactical withdrawal intended to pave the way for Britain’s return to the former $4.8665 parity with the American dollar.
column2: 英国被迫在1919年4月放弃黄金兑换，这是英国准备回到从前一英镑兑换4.8665美元等价的战术性撤退。

column1: Six years later, in April 1925, Britain confirmed its monetary credibility and returned to the gold standard.
column2: 六年之后，在1925年4月，英国确认其货币信誉并且返回金本位制。

column1: But the pound had already suffered irreparable damage.
column2: 但是英镑已经遭受了不可弥补的损害。

column1: The experience of 1914 implies that a credible alternative can replace an entrenched world currency, especially after an unfavorable balance of trade has weakened it.
column2: 1914年的经验表明，具有可信度的替换货币可以取代地位牢靠的世界货币，特别是在不良贸易平衡削弱这一货币之后。

column1: But even then, dethroning the reigning king of international exchange takes time.
column2: 但是即使在那时，夺取国际交易国王宝座还是要假以时日。

column1: Today, the euro – a currency without a country – lacks a long track record of credibility.
column2: 如今，欧元这一没有国度的货币缺乏长久的信誉历史记录。

column1: Thirteen countries in the European Union use the euro as money.
column2: 欧盟的十三个国家使用欧元作为货币。

column1: But the commitment of these independent political entities to the euro cannot match the history of America’s commitment to the dollar.
column2: 但是这些独立政治实体对欧元的承诺却无法与美国对美元的承诺历史相提并论。

column1: The European Central Bank, established in 1998, has a mandate to manage the new currency to maintain price stability.
column2: 欧洲中央银行建立于1998年，其使命是管理这一新货币来维持价格稳定。

column1: But the ECB needs time to establish its inflation-fighting credentials.
column2: 但是欧洲央行需要时间来建立其与通货膨胀作斗争的资格。

column1: It cannot hitch a ride on gold, the way America did a century ago.
column2: 它无法像美国在一个世纪以前那样搭黄金的车。

column1: So the euro must earn its reputation crisis by crisis to confront the dollar’s dominance as the currency of choice for international transactions.
column2: 所以欧元必须通过一个又一个危机来赢得其声誉来对抗美元作为国际交易首选货币的霸主地位。

column1: Recent experience with the euro as an official reserve asset is instructive.
column2: 欧元作为官方储备资产近来的经历颇能说明情况。

column1: Between 2000 and 2005, the dollar lost more than 25% of its value against the euro.
column2: 2000年至2005年期间，美元对欧元贬值25 ％ 。

column1: Meanwhile, the fraction of international reserves held in euros grew from 18% to 24%, and the dollar’s share dropped from 71% to 66%.
column2: 与此同时，欧元在国际储备中持有率从18％上升到24 ％ ， 而美元则从71％下降到66 ％ 。

column1: In short, the euro has clearly made some headway during this period of US balance of payment deficits, but this reflects an evolutionary decline in the dollar’s dominance, not a revolutionary regime shift.
column2: 简而言之，欧元在美国收支平衡赤字期间显然取得了进步，但是这反映出美元霸主地位的演变性下降，而非革命性的大局变动。

column1: What might trigger a fatal run on the dollar in world markets?
column2: 有什么事件可能会触发国际市场上致命性的挤兑美元呢？

column1: While a broad and abrupt sell-off by major foreign holders of dollars – for example, China – appears unlikely, a cataclysmic event, similar to the outbreak of the Great War in 1914, could prompt a search for a new international medium of exchange.
column2: 尽管主要的外国美元持有者例如中国突然间大范围抛售美元看起来不大可能，但是，某一类似于1914年第一次世界大战爆发那样的灾难性事件有可能促使人们寻求一种新的国际交易媒介。

column1: In the modern era of automated payments, the upheaval might come from a terrorist attack that undermines the computerized transfer facilities of the world’s banking system.
column2: 在现代自动支付年代里，这一动荡可能来自某一破坏世界银行体系计算机化的转移设施的恐怖主义袭击。

column1: A catastrophic loss of electronic records could surely destroy the credibility of the dollar as the international medium of exchange.
column2: 电子记录灾难性的丢失几乎会摧毁美元作为国际交易媒介的信誉。

column1: But exactly what would replace the dollar under such circumstances remains an open question.
column2: 但是在这种情况下什么会取代美元还是一个没有答案的问题。

column1: After all, a loss of computer records would make the euro equally suspect.
column2: 毕竟，丢失计算机记录也会让欧元也一样可疑。

column1: Perhaps gold, a store of value impervious to physical distortion, could make a comeback.
column2: 黄金是可以抵御物理变形的价值储备，也许它会卷土重来。

column1: Of course, one can only hope that such a scenario remains pure conjecture.
column2: 当然，人们只能希望这种情形只是一种臆测而已。

column1: Will the Euro Survive the Current Crisis?
column2: 欧元经得住当前的危机吗？

column1: CAMBRIDGE – The European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) and the euro are about to celebrate their tenth anniversary.
column2: 剑桥－欧洲经济与货币联盟(EMU)和欧元快要进行十周年庆了。

column1: The euro was introduced without serious problems and has since functioned well, with the European Central Bank delivering the low inflation that is its sole mandate.
column2: 欧元的引进没有产生严重的问题，并且此后运行良好，与此同时欧洲中央银行将低通胀作为其首要任务

column1: But the current economic crisis may provide a severe test of the euro’s ability to survive in more troubled times.
column2: 但是，当前的经济危机可能对欧元在更困难时期继续运行下去的能力提出了严峻的考验。

column1: While the crisis could strengthen the institutions provided by the EMU, it could also create multiple risks, of which member countries need to be aware if they want to avoid them.
column2: 虽然当前的经济危机可能加强欧洲经济与货币联盟提供的制度机构，但是也可能产生多重风险。 如果欧洲经济与货币联盟的成员国想要避免这些风险，它们就必须意识到这些风险。

column1: The primary problem is that conditions in individual EMU members may develop in such different ways that some national political leaders could be tempted to conclude that their countries would be better served by adopting a mix of policies different from that of the other members.
column2: 主要问题是，单个的欧洲经济与货币联盟成员国国情的发展可能非常不同，以至于一些国家的政治领导人可能倾向于认为，他们的国家通过采取和其他成员国不同的各种政策，对国家更为有利。

column1: The current differences in the interest rates of euro-zone government bonds show that the financial markets regard a break-up as a real possibility.
column2: 目前欧元区政府债券利率的差异表明，金融市场认为欧洲经济与货币联盟的分裂是一个现实的可能。

column1: Ten-year government bonds in Greece and Ireland, for example, now pay nearly a full percentage point above the rate on comparable German bonds, and Italy’s rate is almost as high.
column2: 例如，希腊和爱尔兰的十年期政府债券现在支付的利率，和可比较的德国政府债券比起来，几乎整整高了一个百分点，而意大利的债券利率几乎也一样高。

column1: There have, of course, been many examples in history in which currency unions or single-currency states have broken up.
column2: 当然，历史上有很多货币联盟或单一货币国家分裂的例子。

column1: Although there are technical and legal reasons why such a split would be harder for an EMU country, there seems little doubt that a country could withdraw if it really wanted to.
column2: 虽然对欧洲经济与货币联盟成员国来说，因为技术和法律上的原因，这样的分裂更为困难，但是，如果欧洲经济与货币联盟成员国真地想退出，就可以退出，人们对此的疑问似乎很少。

column1: The most obvious reason that a country might choose to withdraw is to escape from the one-size-fits-all monetary policy imposed by the single currency.
column2: 欧洲经济与货币联盟成员国可能选择退出的最明显的原因，是为了避免因为单一货币所造成的不区分具体情形而适用于所有成员国的货币政策。

column1: A country that finds its economy very depressed during the next few years, and fears that this will be chronic, might be tempted to leave the EMU in order to ease monetary conditions and devalue its currency.
column2: 一个发现其经济在未来几年会很萧条而且担心萧条会延续很长时间的成员国，可能会为了缓和其货币状况并且使其货币贬值，而倾向于离开欧洲经济与货币联盟。

column1: Although that may or may not be economically sensible, a country in a severe economic downturn might very well take such a policy decision.
column2: 虽然这样做在经济上可能是明智的，也可能是不明智的，但是，一个遭受严重经济下滑的国家极有可能做出这样的政策决策

column1: The Stability and Growth Pact, which limits euro-zone members’ fiscal deficits, is another reason why a country might want to leave the EMU.
column2: 限制欧元区成员国财政赤字的《稳定和增长公约 》 ， 是另一个欧洲经济与货币联盟成员国想退出联盟的原因。

column1: In a serious downturn, a country may wish to pursue a traditional Keynesian policy through large-scale, deficit-financed fiscal stimulus.
column2: 在经济严重下滑的时候，一个国家可能希望通过大规模的扩大财政赤字的财政刺激方案，来实施传统的凯恩斯政策。

column1: Although the Stability and Growth Pact may be elastic enough to permit some deficit stimulus, a country may feel constrained from acting as aggressively as it wants.
column2: 虽然《稳定和增长公约》可能有足够的弹性来允许一些成员国的赤字刺激方案，但是，有些国家仍然可能会觉得不能像自己想的那样采取激进的措施。

column1: The current financial crisis raises yet another problem: the lack of a clear “lender of last resort.”
column2: 当前的金融危机还提出了另一个问题：缺少一个明确的“最后贷款人 ” 。

column1: It remains to be seen how willing the ECB will be to provide national central banks with the volume of euros needed to play this role fully.
column2: 欧洲中央银行给欧洲经济与货币联盟成员国的中央银行提供完全扮演这一角色所需的欧元数量的意愿，还有待观察。

column1: If a country sees its banks failing because its national bank cannot lend them enough, it may chose to leave the EMU so that its central bank can provide whatever amount of local currency it deems necessary.
column2: 如果一个国家因为它的国家银行不能借给它足够的钱，而认为其银行不起作用，它可能会选择退出欧洲经济与货币联盟，以便其中央银行能够提供其认为必要的无论多大数量的本国货币。

column1: Moreover, the current economic crisis has led to renewed talk about the need for the European Union to have taxing authority.
column2: 而且，目前的经济危机导致了对欧盟拥有征税权力必要性的重新讨论。

column1: Whatever the logic of that proposition, it would open the door to much greater income redistribution.
column2: 不管这种必要性主张的逻辑是什么，它都会为更大的收入再分配打开大门。

column1: High-income countries might find that reason enough to want out.
column2: 高收入国家可能会发现这个理由对退出欧洲经济与货币联盟来说，已经足够了。

column1: Even if officials do not want to abandon the euro, they may come to do so as a result of a strategy of trying to get other countries to agree to a policy change.
column2: 即使官员们不想放弃欧元，但是，作为使其他成员国同意进行政策变化的策略的结果，他们也有可能这样做。

column1: A country that believes that monetary or fiscal policy is too tight may threaten to leave if policy is not changed.
column2: 一个认为货币或财政政策太紧的国家，可能会扬言如果不改变政策，就退出欧洲经济与货币联盟。

column1: That is clearly a substantial risk if the country is Germany or France.
column2: 如果上述国家是德国或法国的话，这显然是一个重大的风险。

column1: But even if it is one of the smaller countries, it might be a serious threat because it could be seen as the beginning of the end.
column2: 但是，即便是欧洲经济与货币联盟中的一个小国，这也可能是一个严重的威胁，因为它会被看成是结束的开始。

column1: So either type of country could make the threat in the hope that it would be enough to cause their EMU colleagues to agree to their desired change in policy.
column2: 因此，大国和小国都能发出威胁，并希望这些威胁就足够使其欧洲经济与货币联盟中的同事同意他们想要的政策变化。

column1: The risk, of course, is that the other countries may not be intimidated.
column2: 当然，这样做的风险是其他国家可能不受胁迫。

column1: The threatening country would then have to choose whether to accepting a humiliating defeat and stay, or stand on “principle” and leave.
column2: 那么，发出威胁的国家将不得不选择是接受羞辱性的失败留下来，还是坚持“原则”退出。

column1: All of this assumes that political leaders would select only a policy change that they think will be in their nation’s long-term interest.
column2: 所有这些，都是假设政治领导人只选择了他们认为符合其国家长远利益的一个政策变化。

column1: But there is also a risk that some politicians act solely out of self-interest, seizing on the economic downturn as an opportunity to get elected by promising to withdraw the country from the EMU, or by saying that they will threaten to do so if the other member countries do not agree to their proposed policy changes.
column2: 但是，也有一些政治家仅仅出于自身利益，通过承诺使国家退出欧洲经济与货币联盟，或者声称如果其他成员国不同意他们提议的政策变化他们就扬言退出的方式，抓住经济下滑问题，将其作为使自己当选的机会。

column1: None of these risks implies that the monetary union will inevitably be a victim of this severe economic downturn.
column2: 这些风险中的任何一个都不意味着，货币联盟将不可避免的成为此次严重经济下滑的牺牲品。

column1: But the downturn will be a more severe test for the euro than any that it faced during its first ten years.
column2: 但是，经济下滑和欧元在其第一个十年中面临的其他考验相比，要严峻得多。

column1: Will the IMF Stand Up to Europe?
column2: IMF会力挺欧洲吗？

column1: CAMBRIDGE – As the eurozone crisis continues to deepen, the International Monetary Fund may finally be acknowledging the need to reassess its approach.
column2: 坎布里奇 — — 随着欧元区危机的继续深化，IMF或将不得不承认有必要反思其作为了。

column1: New Managing Director Christine Lagarde’s recent call for forced recapitalization of Europe’s bankrupt banking system is a good start.
column2: 新总裁拉加德最近提出应该对欧洲已经破产的银行体系强行予以重组，这是个不错的开始。

column1: European officials’ incensed reaction – the banks are fine, they insist, and need only liquidity support – should serve to buttress the Fund’s determination to be sensible about Europe.
column2: 欧洲官员被激怒了，他们坚持说，银行们一切都好，需要的只是流动性支持。 欧洲官员的态度应该能够支持IMF对欧洲的判断的可靠性。

column1: Until now, the Fund has sycophantically supported each new European initiative to rescue the over-indebted eurozone periphery, committing more than $100 billion to Greece, Portugal, and Ireland so far.
column2: 到目前为止，对于欧洲所提出的任何救助债务深重的欧元区外围国家的方案，IMF无不大力支持，其热情程度甚至有阿谀奉承之嫌。 希勒、葡萄牙和爱尔兰已经获得了超过1000亿美元援助承诺。

column1: Unfortunately, the IMF is risking not only its members’ money, but, ultimately, its own institutional credibility.
column2: 不幸的是，IMF这么做不仅是在拿其成员国的钱冒险，更严重的是，归根到底，它所押上的赌注是自己的机构名誉。

column1: Only a year ago, at the IMF’s annual meeting in Washington, DC, senior staff were telling anyone who would listen that the whole European sovereign-debt panic was a tempest in a teapot.
column2: 一年前，在IMF华盛顿年会上，只要你愿意听，高级官员就会告诉你，整个欧洲主权债务危机纯属小题大做。

column1: Using slick PowerPoint presentations with titles like “Default in Today’s Advanced Economies: Unnecessary, Undesirable, and Unlikely,” the Fund tried to convince investors that eurozone debt was solid as a rock.
column2: IMF制作了精美的PPT，打着《今日发达经济体的违约：没有必要、不受欢迎、断无可能》之类的标题，试图让投资者相信，欧元区坚如磐石。

column1: Even for Greece, the IMF argued, debt dynamics were not a serious concern, thanks to anticipated growth and reforms.
column2: 即使对于希腊，IMF也认为其债务动态并无值得深虑的必要，因为该地区增长强劲，而且会实施改革。

column1: Never mind the obvious flaw in the Fund’s logic, namely that countries such as Greece and Portugal face policy and implementation risks far more akin to emerging markets than to truly advanced economies such as Germany and the United States.
column2: IMF这么说存在明显的逻辑漏洞：希腊和葡萄牙这样的国家，它们所面临的政策和实施政策的风险更接近于新兴市场，而不是德国和美国这样的真正发达国家。 但那又怎么样呢。

column1: As the situation deteriorated, one might have guessed that the IMF would mark its beliefs to market, as it were, and adopt a more cautious tone.
column2: 随着情况的恶化，你也许会认为IMF将向往常一样信赖市场，并在放话时采取更加谨慎的语调。

column1: Instead, at the IMF’s April 2011 interim meeting, a senior official declared that the Fund now considers troubled Spain to be a core eurozone country like Germany, rather than a peripheral country like Greece, Portugal, or Ireland.
column2: 但是，在2011年4月的IMF中期会议上，一位高级官员宣称，IMF将陷入困境的西班牙视为和德国同等的欧元区核心国家，而不是像希腊、葡萄牙和爱尔兰这样的外围国家。

column1: Evidently, investors were supposed to infer that for all practical purposes they should think of Spanish and German debt as identical – the old hubris of the eurozone.
column2: 显然，他们认为务实的投资者会因此推断，西班牙和德国债务完全等价 — — 此乃欧元区固有的傲慢。

column1: My own sarcastic reaction was to think, “Oh, now the IMF thinks that some of the core eurozone countries are a default risk.”
column2: 我不无讽刺地想 ： “ 哦，现在IMF认为某些欧元区核心国家也存在违约风险了 。 ”

column1: Having served as the IMF’s chief economist from 2001 to 2003, I am familiar with the Fund’s need to walk a tightrope between building investor confidence and shaking up complacent policymakers.
column2: 作为2001—2003年IMF首席经济学家，我十分熟悉IMF的处境 — — 它需要在提振投资者的信心和威慑踌躇满志的政客之间走钢丝。

column1: But it is one thing to be circumspect in the midst of a crisis; it is quite another to spew nonsense.
column2: 但在危机中保持细心周到是一回事，信口胡说则是完全不同的另一回事。

column1: The late Chicago-school economist George Stigler would have described the IMF’s role in Europe as reflecting acute “regulatory capture.”
column2: 已故的芝加哥学派经济学家乔治·斯蒂格勒会把IMF在欧洲的角色称为病入膏肓的“监管俘虏 ” 。

column1: Simply put, Europe and the US control too much power in the IMF, and their thinking is too dominant.
column2: 在IMF，欧洲和美国把持了太多的权力，在行为方式中占据了太大的主导地位。

column1: What European leaders may want most from the Fund are easy loans and strong rhetorical support.
column2: 欧洲领导人最希望从IMF手中获得的是宽松的贷款和给力的口头支持。

column1: But what Europe really needs is the kind of honest assessment and tough love that the Fund has traditionally offered to its other, less politically influential, clients.
column2: 但欧洲实际上需要的是诚实的评估和苦口良药，即IMF传统上对政治影响力较低的客户所做的那些事。

column1: The IMF’s blind spot in dealing with Europe until now is only partly due to European voting power.
column2: 在应对欧洲问题上，IMF至今仍存在盲区，欧洲在IMF所拥有的投票权只是原因之一。

column1: It also stems from an “us” and “them” mentality that similarly permeates research at the top Wall Street investment houses.
column2: “我们”和“他们”有别的心态也是IMF不能客观行事的原因，这一点在华尔街顶级投资机构的研究中也存在。

column1: Analysts who have worked their entire lives only on advanced economies have learned to bet on things going well, because for the couple of decades prior to the crisis, things mostly did go well – very well.
column2: 一辈子都在研究发达经济体的分析师得到的经验是凡事朝好的方向看，因为从危机前的20年来看，一切都会好的 — — 是大好不是小好。

column1: That is why, for example, so many keep assuming that a normal rapid recovery is just around the corner.
column2: 这就是为什么很多人认为正常的快速复苏马上就会到来的原因。

column1: But the financial crisis should have reminded everyone that the distinction between advanced economies and emerging markets is not a bright red line.
column2: 但金融危机提醒所有人，发达经济体和新兴市场之间的区别并不是不可跨越的鸿沟。

column1: In his recent speech in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, US Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke forcefully complained that political paralysis has possibly become the principal impediment to recovery.
column2: 在最新的俄怀明州杰克森霍尔讲话中，美联储主席伯南克大力抨击了政治僵局，指出这可能已经成为复苏的最大障碍。

column1: But analysts accustomed to working on emerging markets understand that such paralysis is very difficult to avoid after a financial crisis.
column2: 但习惯于研究新兴市场的分析师早就明白，类似的政治僵局在金融危机爆发后是很难避免的。

column1: Rather than slavishly believing policymakers’ assurances, emerging-market researchers have learned to be cynical about official promises.
column2: 新兴市场研究员才不会盲信政客的信誓旦旦，他们早就学会了对官方承诺持怀疑态度。

column1: All too often, everything that can be done wrong will be done wrong.
column2: 只要是可能做错的事，最后无一幸免地都出了错，这样例子发生得还少吗？

column1: The IMF needs to bring much more of this brand of skepticism to its assessment of eurozone debt dynamics, instead of constantly seeking strained assumptions that would make the debt appear sustainable.
column2: IMF需要更多地怀疑它对欧元区债务动态所做的评估，而不是不遗余力地寻找站不住脚的假设证明债务仍然可持续。

column1: Anyone looking closely at Europe’s complex options for extricating itself from its debt straightjacket should realize that political constraints will be a huge obstacle no matter which route Europe takes.
column2: 任何近距离观察欧洲为将自己救出债务缠身状态所面临的复杂选择的人都应该意识到，不管欧洲选择哪条路，政治约束将成为巨大障碍。

column1: Even outside Europe, the IMF has long given too much credence to sitting governments, rather than focusing on the long-term interests of the country and its people.
column2: 即使在欧洲之外，IMF也总是过分迁就在任政府，而不是专注于一国及其人民的长期利益。

column1: The Fund is doing Europe’s people no favor by failing to push aggressively for a more realistic solution, including dramatic debt write-downs for peripheral eurozone countries and re-allocating core-country guarantees elsewhere.
column2: 为欧洲人民着想，IMF应该大力推行更现实的解决方案，包括对外围欧元区国家的大规模债务减记并重新分配核心国家对其他国家的担保。

column1: Now that the Fund has squarely acknowledged the huge capital holes in many European banks, it should start pressing forcefully for a comprehensive and credible solution to the eurozone debt crisis, a solution that will involve either partial breakup of the eurozone or fundamental constitutional reform.
